Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Traumatic Brain Injury Detection and Reporting System
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research team has developed a Reactive Mobile Head-impact Application (RMHA) to support the detection, assessment and monitoring of head impacts of sports players. This is a person-centered reporting tool that consists of impact detecting sensors that fit comfortable inside a football helmet coupled with computer software that automatically collects and stores impact data with the ability to send real-time alerts to medical personnel if a player suffers a severe head impact. The proposed innovation could make significant advancements in low-cost remote monitoring technologies and retrofitted sensor technologies. RMHA could facilitate long-term data collection that allows teams to compile a "lifetime" record of all notable head impacts that the player has received. The software will cross integrate with existing data collection methods and work with helmet safety standards organizations to ultimately create safer equipment. Overall, the RMHA can provide inputs for detecting and determining at-risk individuals. The proposed innovation can also be applicable to a variety of other domains where head impacts are common such as military use.

The RMHA technology could have significant impacts for the general population, providing a technology to facilitate early monitoring and assessment of head impacts to detect and report injuries for young athletes in all sports during their careers. This technology can help players, coaches and medical personnel better understand the consequences of players' head impacts and could impact safety decisions in the future. The real-time monitoring aspect of this technology would enable a faster medical response when players suffer significant head injuries due to impact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation (NSF) Innovation Corps (I-Corps) project, “Traumatic Brain Injury Detection and Reporting System,” was carried out by Eric L. Luster (entrepreneurial lead), Troy McDaniel (I-Corps business mentor) and Jay Klein (principal investigator).

Upon entering the NSF I-Corps program, the proposed technology was a wearable sensor system for detecting and reporting head impacts following potential concussion-causing collisions. The target area of focus was youth football. Our team believed that this technology would be groundbreaking in the area of activity monitoring, wearable technologies and data visualization. While we set out to focus on youth football, we believed that there were additional areas that could benefit from the proposed technology. For example, we believed the technology would be ideal for use by the military, construction personnel and in skiing, skateboarding, snowboarding, jet-skiing, motorcycle riding, racecar driving and professional sports.

During the NSF I-Corps workshop held at Georgia Tech, our team was introduced to the process of customer discovery, in which we learned how to identify our potential customers and how to formulate proper questions based upon a hypothesis. Customer discovery involves “getting out of the building” and speaking to real people to gain a better understanding of the problems our potential customers would like solved. Through customer discovery, our team gained new insights and knowledge about what was really important to them.

Customer discovery led us to change our emphasis from the initial design of installing sensors exclusively in football helmets, to installing sensors inside a headband-style garment for future use across multiple sports including soccer, basketball, and hockey.

This resulted in the development of a headband design for a low cost, lightweight, and rugged prototype that is machine washable and can accommodate the equipment needed for detecting and reporting a head impact following a potential concussion-causing collision. Once this embedded headband prototype is integrated with software (to be developed), the result will be a complete prototype that has the potential of being tested in a number of sports domains.

While engaging the development of a prototype, a diverse team comprised of undergraduate and graduate students, seasoned industry professionals in manufacturing and industrial design, and Arizona State University faculty was assembled. Students working on the project received direct mentoring from industry professionals who were contracted for specific deliverables. This hands-on experience and mentoring from industry professionals in developing and delivering something tangible has given these students (many of whom are from underrepresented groups) a unique experience that is rarely available in academic settings. This experience and the mentoring the students received are expected to improve their employability in the areas of science and engineering.
